video_title: The Scariest Level of Discipline: The Gyo-ji System

scenes.text: There exists a level of discipline so absolute that it evokes fear in others. It is the frightening consistency of those who never fail, who show up when every excuse suggests they shouldn't.
scenes.image_prompt: generate an image in the style of a renaissance painting: A stoic figure standing amidst a swirling storm, illuminated by a single heavenly beam of light, while others in the shadows are collapsing in exhaustion. Use dramatic chiaroscuro.

scenes.text: When you reach this state, society no longer calls you disciplined; they say you are 'not normal'. This is the result of Gyo-ji, an ancient Zen system from Japan designed to create unbreakable consistency.
scenes.image_prompt: generate an image in the style of a renaissance painting: A portrait of a Zen master with intense, piercing eyes, holding a wooden staff, set against a dark, textured background with soft sfumato edges.

scenes.text: Meet Raphael, a successful programmer who was a victim of his own brain. He suffered from a cycle of total motivation on Monday, mental negotiation by Wednesday, and complete surrender by Friday.
scenes.image_prompt: generate an image in the style of a renaissance painting: A scholar at a cluttered wooden desk, head in hands, surrounded by discarded scrolls and books, lit by a single flickering candle. The mood is one of profound melancholy.

scenes.text: He tried every modern tool—apps, rewards, accountability partners—but nothing worked because he was fighting the very architecture of his brain.
scenes.image_prompt: generate an image in the style of a renaissance painting: An anatomical study of a human brain surrounded by complex gears and clockwork mechanisms that are rusted and breaking. Inspired by Da Vinci’s sketches.
